PRE-MARKET AUSTRALIAN AND JAPANESE STOCK NEWS: ANZ Bank set to sideline IPO plans for UDC Finance, WTI rose 1.2%, Sony to buy remaining EMI stake and book JPY 100bln profit with the acquisition, South Korea shut for holiday
content:
AUSTRALIA

ANZ Bank (ANZ AT)
- Co. is said to put aside IPO plan for UDC Finance unit. (Newswires)

CBA (CBA AT)
- Co. is to face an examination by the banking royal commission regarding its handling of small business loans picked up from acquisition of Bankwest in 2008, although the commission effectively cleared CBA of conspiracy. (The Australian/ AFR)

Healthscope (HSO AT)
- Co. said to have received several approaches for its Asian pathology business. (Newswires)
- Co. guides FY18 results to include non-operating impairment charge of AUD 68mln, as well as AUD17mln impairment related to asset write downs.
- Co. affirms FY18 hospital EBITDA AUD 340mln-350mln which is broadly inline Y/Y, while it targets FY19 to grow at minimum of 10% Y/Y.  

HT&E Limited (HT1 AT)
- APN Outdoor (APO AT) submitted proposal for Co.’s Adshel business which was greater than offer from oOh!Media (OML AT). (Newswires)

James Hardie Industries (JHX AT)
- Co. FY17 net AUD 146.1mln vs. Prev. AUD 276mln Y/Y, rev. AUD 2.05bln vs. Prev. AUD 1.92bln Y/Y. (Newswires)

 Macquarie Infrastructure (MIG AT)
- Co. directors were reappointed although it was said to be a gruelling vote with 40% voting against the reappointment. (Newswires)

Energy
- WTI crude rose 1.2%. (Newswires)

JAPAN

Kansai Electric (9503 JT)
- Co. is said to be reducing electricity bills as soon as July. (Newswires)

Konica Minolta Holdings (4902 JT)
- Co. acquires MacProfessionals, although no terms have been disclosed. (Newswires)

Sony (6758 JT)
- Co. to buy Mubadala consortium’s 60% stake in EMI Music Publishing for USD 1.9bln and will book JPY 100bln profit with acquisition of rest of EMI stake. (Newswires)

Takeda (4502 JT)
- Co. is to issue as much as USD 20bln in bonds to help fund Shire acquisition. (Nikkei)

Other News
- Reports note documents which suggest PM Abe had prior knowledge that a school operator run by friend Kotaro Kake was planning on building a vet school as early as 2015, despite the PM stating at the Diet he was unaware until was given approval by the government in 2017 amid accusations he used his influence to get approval for the project. (Nikkei)

SOUTH KOREA

Hyundai Motor (005380 KS)
- Co. retracted spinoff merger plan for Hyundai Mobis (012330 KS) and Hyundai Glovis due to unfavourable market opinion and shareholder opposition. (Newswires)

DAILY ASIA-PAC OPENING NEWS
content:
ASIA-PAC

China Vice Premier Liu said China will actively increase imports, while there were also separate reports that China is said to consider ending birth limits as soon as this year. (Newswires)


EU

Italy's M5S leader Di Maio said that Conte will be premier of the government. (ANSA)
Note: Conte is a 54-year-old lawyer and private law professor who was being touted as the front-runner for PM.

Italy's President Mattarella reportedly expressed concerns with the M5S/League fiscal plan and is said to need time to mull the PM choice. Furthermore, Mattarella was reported to demand leaders of Italy’s Lower and Upper House to attend a meeting on Tuesday. (Newswires)


FX

USD ended Monday’s session on a mixed footing vs G10 peers though initial momentum was seen on the back of US and China reciprocal suspension of import tariffs. The DXY is back below 94.000 around 93.700 vs a new YTD peak at 94.064, with the Greenback’s dollar rivals among the outperformers. EUR saw an impressive comeback from new 2018 lows vs the USD with the headline pair firmly above 1. 1750. However, 1.1800 is capping recovery gains. AUD extended relative gains vs the USD with the aid of M&A-related news as US’ Harbour upped its bid for Santos to Usd10.8 bn. AUDUSD rebounded above 0.7550 where a big option expiry rolled off at the NY cut (1.8 bn), and with approx. 4bln still in play from Tuesday to Friday between 0.7450-0.7550. Note, market contacts believe that stops lie on a break above 0.7565 ahead of all that.
CAD pulled back a tad further from recent peaks above 1.2900 to under 1.2850 amidst elevated oil prices and more sabre-rattling from US Secretary of State Pompeo on Iran, which together seemed to nullify negativity surrounding no NAFTA deal. The Kiwi benefited from broader USD consolidation to reclaim 0.6900+ status and recover losses made overnight on the back of a notable NZ retail sales data miss.


COMMODITIES

US President Trump signed order on Venezuela preventing the selling-off of Venezuelan accounts receivable related to oil, according to a senior US Official. Elsewhere, US Secretary of State Pompeo stated the US will take 'swift economic and diplomatic actions to help the restoration of Venezuela's democracy. (Newswires)

OPEC is looking closely at Venezuelan oil drop to see if the loss of supply from the country warrants actions by the group, according to sources. (Newswires)
 

GEOPOLITICAL

US Secretary of State Mike Pompeo said US sanctions on Iran will be the strongest in history and that Tehran will be battling to keep its economy alive once they come into full effect. In related news, a Pentagon spokesperson said the US will take 'all necessary steps to confront and address Iran's malign influence in the region'. (Newswires)
 

US

Fed's Bostic (voter, dovish) said he sees 2 more rate hikes in 2018 and that it remains to be seen how much slack remains in the US economy. (Newswires)

Fed's Harker (non-voter, dovish) initially stated he sees two more rates hike this year but could potentially support an additional hike if inflation accelerates, although he is not seeing signs of that yet. Harker also said he favours pausing hikes once the Fed has hit neutral rates, while he later provided a conflicting remark that he would support three more hikes in 2018 if inflation is sustained at current levels. (Newswires)

US Economic Adviser Kudlow commented on Chinese negotiations in which he stated that the fine print and details will come later, while he also noted that they were making terrific progress and that Commerce Secretary Ross will work through details over the next couple of weeks. Furthermore, NEC Director Kudlow also stated a renewed NAFTA deal is not dead and that the congressional timetable may be flexible. (Newswires)

US Trade Representative Lighthizer said he still sees the need of real work to achieve changes in China and noted that intellectual property issues are more important than the trade gap. (Newswires)

US Commerce Department said it will impose anti-dumping rate of 200% and countervailing rate of 256% on some cold-rolled steel from Vietnam produced using substrate originating from China. (Newswires)


MARKET RECAP

US equity futures gapped higher at the re-open on Sunday, underpinned by weekend comments from US Treasury Secretary Mnuchin, who suggested a trade dispute with China was being put on hold as talks – which have made progress – continue. The ES jumped to slightly above the 2730 level, and caught a bid towards 2740 at the cash equity open, before paring back to 2730. As the session wore on, ES was drifting between 2730-2740 in quiet trade, with the Canadians and a lot of Europe away for Whit Monday and Victoria Day respectively. The Dow, meanwhile, was generally trading around the 25,000 mark, having breached it to the upside for the first time since March. All sectors traded in positive territory, industrials and tech outperformed amid US and China temporarily holding off tariffs. The telecom sector also printed notable gains approaching 2% after Comcast (CMCSA) has said to purchase assets for Fox (FOXA) for USD 60bln if AT&T (T) wins the battle with the Department of Justice for the merger with Time Warner (TWX).

In M&A news, General Electric (GE) has reached a USD 11.1bln deal with Wabtec (WAB) over its transportation unit. Fifth Third Bancorp (FITB) and MB Financial (MBFI) entered a merger deal valued at USD 4.37bln, with the former posting losses greater 8%. La Salle Hotel (LHO) is to be acquired by Blackstone (BX) for USD 4.8bln. Elsewhere, HCA Healthcare (HCA) and KKR (KKR) are partnering up to make a bid for Envision Healthcare (EVHC). In stocks specifics, Micron (MU) outperformed in the NASDAQ after lifting its Q3 guidance. Agricultural names, namely Deere (DE) and Caterpillar (CAT), outperformed after US President Trump said that China agreed to purchase a massive amount of agricultural and farm products. Baidu (BIDU) lagged its peers in the NASDAQ after entering an agreement to divest its Global DU business. Finally, Alphabet’s Google (GOOGL) may be facing a USD 4.3bln claim in the UK after it improperly obtained data from iPhones. SPX +0.73% at 2732, NDX +0.57% at 6906, DJI +1.20% at 25011.

The yield curve flattened modestly on Monday with most of the action concentrated in the short end of the curve, 2yr yields were higher by c.2bps amid some of Europe away from market and ahead of Fed minutes this week. 2s5s and 2s10s were narrower by c.1bps at settlement. The sell-off was helped by positive news on the US-China front, though ranges and volumes were thin for the session. This week the  US will auction 2s, 5s and 7s. The US Treasury increased the auction sizes at the most recent refunding announcement and will auction a total of USD 115bln in 2-year notes (USD 33bln, today), 5-year notes (USD 36bln, Wednesday) and 7-year notes (USD 30bln, Thursday), as well as 2y FRNs (USD 16bln, Wednesday) this week. With a total of USD 70.6bln maturing, the auction will raise net USD 44.4bln in the week. The last auction, in April, was poor; the line was covered just 2.61x, below the 6-auction average of 2.81x, the auction also tailed by 0.5bps and dealers were left with a larger than average chunk of the issuance. US 10yr T-Notes futures settled 10+ ticks higher at 118-27.

US MARKET WRAP 21 May 2018: US-China trade ceasefire lifts stocks
content:
• * SNAP-SHOT: Equities up, Treasuries down, DXY flat, Crude up.
  • * REAR-VIEW: US/China conciliatory trade talk, Italian President has concerns over M5S/League fiscal plan, heavy M&A
  • * AHEAD: BoJ core CPI overnight, APIs on Tuesday, heavy BoE speak, ECB’s Liikanen, UK/EU trade talks and 2yr Note auction

* TRADE: Trade news flow dominated on Monday after China and the US have agreed over the weekend to place their trade dispute on hold. US President Trump on Monday said that China has agreed to buy "massive amounts of additional farm/agricultural products". US Economic Adviser Kudlow said (on Chinese negotiations) that “the fine print, the details will come later. We’re making terrific progress,” adding that Commerce Secretary Ross will work through details over the next couple weeks. US Trade Representative Lightizer once again provided a reality check to Mnuchin’s optimism, arguing that there was still a need to complete real work to achieve changes; he also added that intellectual property issues were far more crucial than the trade gap. On the China front, Vice Premier Liu said China will actively increase imports.

* ITALIAN POLITICS: President Mattarella held talks on Monday with M5S leader Di Maio and League’s leader Salvini to agree on a PM for the coalition government. Among others, 54 year old Lawyer and Private Law professor Conte has been touted to be the front-runner for the role, with M5S leader Di Maio confirming later that Conte should be taking the position. The League leader Salvini said the European Commission must not worry, though he said he would place Italy's national interest first, noting the primary goal is to reduce debt. Later, President Mattarella urged leaders of the Lower an Upper House to attend a meeting on Tuesday, and expressed concerns with M5S/League fiscal plan, and has reportedly requested more time to mull PM choice.

* NAFTA: US Treasury Secretary Mnuchin said there are still some significant, open issues regarding NAFTA, and it might be easier to pass a ‘skinny’ NAFTA deal if negotiations don’t go as planned. NEC Director Kudlow noted a renewed NAFTA deal is not dead, adding the congressional timetable may be flexible.

*GEOPOLITICS: US Secretary of State Pompeo said that the Iran nuclear deal would put the world at risk, and that the US would not renegotiate it; he also threatened Iran with “unprecedented financial” pressures. Iran's Rouhani responded, and told Pompeo the world does not accept the US deciding for every country.

* FED SPEAK: Fed's Bostic (Voter, Dovish) said that there is case for 2 rate additional hikes this year, and noted it is yet to be seen how much slack remains in the economy. He also added the US is close to full employment and nearing the Fed’s inflation target, with inflation likely to rise above 2% for a while. He sees the possible use of price-level targeting to offset low neutral rate. Fed's Kashkari (Non-voter, Dove) reiterated that Fed should not move too fast to raise rates. Fed's Harker (Non-voter, Dovish) sees two rates hike this year, but could potentially support an additional hike if inflation accelerates, though he is not seeing signs of that yet. Harker favours pausing hikes once the Fed has hit neutral rates.

* EQUITIES: * EQUITIES: SPX +0.73% at 2732, NDX +0.57% at 6906, DJI +1.20% at 25011.  SECTORS: Cons Cyclicals +0.33%, Cons Non-Cyclicals: +0.28%, Energy: +0.94%, Financials: +0.70%, Health Care: +0.02%, Industrials: +1.43%, Materials: +0.51%.

US equity futures gapped higher at the re-open on Sunday, underpinned by weekend comments from US Treasury Secretary Mnuchin, who suggested a trade dispute with China was being put on hold as talks – which have made progress – continue. The ES jumped to slightly above the 2730 level, and caught a bid towards 2740 at the cash equity open, before paring back to 2730. As the session wore on, ES was drifting between 2730-2740 in quiet trade, with the Canadians and a lot of Europe away for Whit Monday and Victoria Day respectively. The Dow, meanwhile, was generally trading around the 25,000 mark, having breached it to the upside for the first time since March.

All sectors traded in positive territory, industrials and tech outperformed amid US and China temporarily holding off tariffs. The telecom sector also printed notable gains approaching 2% after Comcast (CMCSA) has said to purchase assets for Fox (FOXA) for USD 60bln if AT&T (T) wins the battle with the Department of Justice for the merger with Time Warner (TWX).

In M&A news, General Electric (GE) has reached a USD 11.1bln deal with Wabtec (WAB) over its transportation unit. Fifth Third Bancorp (FITB) and MB Financial (MBFI) entered a merger deal valued at USD 4.37bln, with the former posting losses greater 8%. La Salle Hotel (LHO) is to be acquired by Blackstone (BX) for USD 4.8bln. Elsewhere, HCA Healthcare (HCA) and KKR (KKR) are partnering up to make a bid for Envision Healthcare (EVHC).

In stocks specifics, Micron (MU) outperformed in the NASDAQ after lifting its Q3 guidance. Agricultural names, namely Deere (DE) and Caterpillar (CAT), outperformed after US President Trump said that China agreed to purchase a massive amount of agricultural and farm products. Baidu (BIDU) lagged its peers in the NASDAQ after entering an agreement to divest its Global DU business. Finally, Alphabet’s Google (GOOGL) may be facing a USD 4.3bln claim in the UK after it improperly obtained data from iPhones.

*CRUDE: WTI crude futures settle USD 0.96 higher at USD 72.24/bbl, Brent futures settle USD 0.71 higher at USD 79.22/bbl.

Crude oil jumped on Monday partly in response to lingering geopolitical concerns (US Secretary of State Pompeo says the US will take 'swift economic and diplomatic actions' to help the restoration of Venezuela’s democracy – sources also reported that OPEC is looking closely at Venezuelan oil output declines to see if the loss of supply from the country warrants actions by the group), but also on the back of supply-side disruptions, with demand-side headlines (IEA's Birol sees initial signs of a slowdown in demand and they are ready to act) unable to halt the rise. Other supply-side issues also played a role (Shell reported that the force majeure is still in place on Bonny Light crude from Nigeria, while Forcardos exports are seen falling to 195k BPD in January vs 298k BPD in February); news that Motiva’s Port Arthur refinery is boosting crude production after  a crude unit restart had little lasting impact. Attention was also on the term-structures, with Brent front-month contracts entering contango, like their US counterparts. For this week's energy inventories estimations are for headline crude to draw 2.8mln, distillates to draw 1.0mln, gasoline to draw 1.1mln.

*TREASURIES: US 10yr T-Notes futures settled 10+ ticks higher at 118-27. The yield curve flattened modestly on Monday with most of the action concentrated in the short end of the curve, 2yr yields were higher by c.2bps amid some of Europe away from market and ahead of Fed minutes this week. 2s5s and 2s10s were narrower by c.1bps at settlement. The sell-off was helped by positive news on the US-China front, though ranges and volumes were thin for the session. This week the  US will auction 2s, 5s and 7s. The US Treasury increased the auction sizes at the most recent refunding announcement and will auction a total of USD 115bln in 2-year notes (USD 33bln, today), 5-year notes (USD 36bln, Wednesday) and 7-year notes (USD 30bln, Thursday), as well as 2y FRNs (USD 16bln, Wednesday) this week. With a total of USD 70.6bln maturing, the auction will raise net USD 44.4bln in the week. The last auction, in April, was poor; the line was covered just 2.61x, below the 6-auction average of 2.81x, the auction also tailed by 0.5bps and dealers were left with a larger than average chunk of the issuance.

*FOREX: USD: Ending Monday’s session on a mixed footing vs G10 peers though initial momentum was seen on the back of US and China reciprocal suspension of import tariffs. The DXY is back below 94.000 around 93.700 vs a new YTD peak at 94.064, with the Greenback’s dollar rivals among the outperformers.

AUD: Extended relative gains vs the USD with the aid of M&A-related news as US’ Harbour upped its bid for Santos to Usd10.8 bn. AUDUSD rebounded above 0.7550 where a big option expiry rolled off at the NY cut (1.8 bn), and with approx. 4bln still in play from Tuesday to Friday between 0.7450-0.7550. Note, market contacts believe that stops lie on a break above 0.7565 ahead of all that.

CAD, NZD: The Loonie pulled back a tad further from recent peaks above 1.2900 to under 1.2850 amidst elevated oil prices and more sabre-rattling from US Secretary of State Pompeo on Iran, which together seemed to nullify negativity surrounding no NAFTA deal. The Kiwi benefited from broader USD consolidation to reclaim 0.6900+ status and recover losses made overnight on the back of a notable NZ retail sales data miss.

EUR: An impressive comeback from new 2018 lows vs the USD with the headline pair firmly above 1. 1750.However, 1.1800 is capping recovery gains.

JPY, GBP, CHF: All laggards and underperformers for the most part. USDJPY saw stops filled at 111.20 at one stage but did not really threaten barrier option supply at 111.50 or exporter offers said to be layered up to 112.00. Cable also fell to fresh YTD lows after stops down through 1.3450 amidst yet more negative Brexit news and talk of Tory in-fighting with some MPs said to be preparing for an Autumn election. However, GBPUSD is back above 1.3400. USDCHF touched parity again before drifting back down.

TRY: Another torrid day for the Lira that plumbed fresh all-time lows vs the USD around 4.6000, with specs/investors far from confident that the CBRT and/or Government will do anything or be able to stop the rot and the next CN policy meeting still some weeks away on June 7.

UBS Weekly FX Flows: USD bid re-emerged while JPY net sold; EUR selling extended for a 7th week
content:
• EURUSD: EURUSD was heavily sold as asset managers led outflows, while private clients and hedge funds recorded moderate inflows.
  • USDJPY, EURJPY: JPY saw outflows vs USD, as strong selling by asset managers and hedge funds exceeded buying by private and corporate clients. EURJPY was net sold, as hedge fund outflows led broad client selling.
  • GBPUSD, EURGBP: GBPUSD was net sold, as hedge fund buying was more than offset by selling from all other client groups. GBP recorded inflows vs EUR for the 6th straight week as all clients registered buying interest except for asset managers.
  • EURCHF, USDCHF: CHF was sold vs EUR, as asset manager buying was more than offset by outflows from all other client groups. USDCHF was marginally sold, as selling by corporates and private clients outweighed hedge fund buying.
  • AUDUSD, NZDUSD, and USDCAD: AUDUSD recorded inflows as buying by corporates and hedge funds outweighed selling by asset managers, while private clients showed limited directionality. NZDUSD was sold for a 5th straight week, as selling by hedge funds dominated buying by all other clients. CAD saw marginal inflows versus USD as all client groups were CAD buyers except for corporates.
  • EURSEK,  EURNOK,  USDSEK,  and  USDNOK:  SEK saw moderate outflows versus EUR as all the client groups showed marginal selling interest except private clients. EURNOK was net sold as outflows from hedge funds and asset managers exceeded inflows from corporates. USDSEK was bought for the 8th straight week; all client groups bought the pair, while private clients showed limited directionality. USDNOK registered inflows, led entirely by hedge fund buying interest.

Daily FX Wrap: Dollar loses some trade traction, Aud outperforms
content:
USD

Ending Monday’s session on a mixed footing vs G10 peers as initial momentum gleaned on a suspension of reciprocal import tariffs between the US and China waned. The DXY is back below 94.000 around 93.700 vs a new ytd peak at 94.064, with the Greenback’s dollar rivals among the outperformers. Note, US Treasury Secretary Mnuchin side-stepped comments on the Dollar, apart from underlying strength is desirable in the longer-term, and steady now is good.

AUD

Extended relative gains vs the Usd with the aid of M&A-related news as US’ Harbour upped its bid for Santos to Usd10.8 bn. Aud/Usd rebounded further above 0.7500 to circa 0.7550 where a big option expiry rolled off at the NY cut (1.8 bn), and with just over 4 bn still in play from Tuesday to Friday between 0.7450-0.7550. Note, market contacts believe that stops lie on a break above 0.7565 ahead of all that.

 CAD/NZD

The Loonie pulled back a tad further from recent peaks above 1.2900 to under 1.2850 amidst elevated oil prices and more sabre-rattling from US Secretary of State Pompeo on Iran, which together seemed to nullify negativity surrounding no NAFTA deal. The Kiwi benefited from broader Usd consolidation to reclaim 0.6900+ status and recover losses made overnight on the back of a notable NZ retail sales data miss.

EUR

An impressive comeback from new 2018 lows vs the Usd just ahead of 1.1700 and key Fib support, with the headline pair bouncing firmly above 1.1750 and above 1 bn option expiry interest at the 1.1760 strike before it ran off. However, 1.1800 is capping recovery gains.

JPY/GBP/CHF  

All laggards and underperformers for the most part, albeit to varying degrees. Usd/Jpy saw stops filled at 111.20 at one stage, but did not really threaten barrier option supply at 111.50 or exporter offers said to be layered up to 112.00. Cable also fell to fresh ytd lows after stops down through 1.3450 amidst yet more negative Brexit news and talk of Tory in-fighting with some MPs said to be preparing for an Autumn election. However, Gbp/Usd is back above 1.3400 vs circa 1.3390. Usd/Chf touched parity again before drifting back down.

TRY  

Another torrid day for the Lira that plumbed fresh all time lows vs the Usd around 4.6000, with specs/investors far from confident that the CBRT and/or Government will do anything, or be able to stop the rot and the next CN policy meeting still some weeks away on June 7.

subject: Daily FX Wrap: Dollar loses some trade traction, Aud outperforms
content:
USD

Ending Monday’s session on a mixed footing vs G10 peers as initial momentum gleaned on a suspension of reciprocal import tariffs between the US and China waned. The DXY is back below 94.000 around 93.700 vs a new ytd peak at 94.064, with the Greenback’s dollar rivals among the outperformers. Note, US Treasury Secretary Mnuchin side-stepped comments on the Dollar, apart from underlying strength is desirable in the longer-term, and steady now is good.

AUD

Extended relative gains vs the Usd with the aid of M&A-related news as US’ Harbour upped its bid for Santos to Usd10.8 bn. Aud/Usd rebounded further above 0.7500 to circa 0.7550 where a big option expiry rolled off at the NY cut (1.8 bn), and with just over 4 bn still in play from Tuesday to Friday between 0.7450-0.7550. Note, market contacts believe that stops lie on a break above 0.7565 ahead of all that.

 CAD/NZD

The Loonie pulled back a tad further from recent peaks above 1.2900 to under 1.2850 amidst elevated oil prices and more sabre-rattling from US Secretary of State Pompeo on Iran, which together seemed to nullify negativity surrounding no NAFTA deal. The Kiwi benefited from broader Usd consolidation to reclaim 0.6900+ status and recover losses made overnight on the back of a notable NZ retail sales data miss.

EUR

An impressive comeback from new 2018 lows vs the Usd just ahead of 1.1700 and key Fib support, with the headline pair bouncing firmly above 1.1750 and above 1 bn option expiry interest at the 1.1760 strike before it ran off. However, 1.1800 is capping recovery gains.

JPY/GBP/CHF  

All laggards and underperformers for the most part, albeit to varying degrees. Usd/Jpy saw stops filled at 111.20 at one stage, but did not really threaten barrier option supply at 111.50 or exporter offers said to be layered up to 112.00. Cable also fell to fresh ytd lows after stops down through 1.3450 amidst yet more negative Brexit news and talk of Tory in-fighting with some MPs said to be preparing for an Autumn election. However, Gbp/Usd is back above 1.3400 vs circa 1.3390. Usd/Chf touched parity again before drifting back down.

TRY  

Another torrid day for the Lira that plumbed fresh all time lows vs the Usd around 4.6000, with specs/investors far from confident that the CBRT and/or Government will do anything, or be able to stop the rot and the next CN policy meeting still some weeks away on June 7.

Italian Premier announcement primer - an insight into the rumored candidates
content:
Giuseppe Conte

The 54 year old Lawyer and Private Law professor is being touted as the front-runner to be Italian Premier. The lawyer of the supreme courts has an academic background that has flowed from the University of Rome to Yale University in the United States with stops at Cambridge University and International Kulture Institute in Vienna. Conte is the co-director of the Laterza series dedicated to “Masters of Law” as well as reportedly being an expert in “company crisis management”. Conte has held a previous position in politics, leading the commission that successfully pushed for the dismissal of councillor Franceso Bellomo whom had “inappropriate actions” with students in preparation for judiciary duties.

Giulio Sapelli

Previously touted as the front runner for Premier, but now fallen to the way-side in favour of Giuseppe Conte, Giulio Sapelli is currently a professor of economic history at the University of Milan and has significant commercial experience having sat on the board of companies such at Unicredit and Eni. The professor who also teaches Political Economy is an editor of the Messenger and is a self-titled “original voice” among Italian economists.

Giampiero Massolo

A further name that has been suggested for the position, but is now expected to be named as foreign minister is Giampiero Massolo. The Italian who was born in Warsaw, Poland, in 1954 is a graduate of Political Science with a specialisation in international politics. Since May 2018 Massolo has served as Chairman of the board of directors of Fincatieri, an Italian shipbuilding company, and has held multiple political positions in the past, with the majority within the foreign affair and foreign ministry positions, and the most notable position being that of head of Italian secret services.

Paolo Savona

Another candidate that has been suggested in popular media as premier previously, but now set for an economic position is that of Paolo Savona, the Italian economist and university professor. Savona has a prolific academic carer and has taught at the Universities of Perugia, Rome Tor Vergata, and Scuola Superiore di Pubblica Amministrazion. The economist has held positions in the Bank of Italy where he spent time as president, the OECD and is currently Chairman of the fintech startup Euklid Ltd. The 82 year old has written papers such as "Why Democracy State and Market failed to protect the system of individual freedoms" which have been critical of recent Italian Governments.

Giancarlo Giorgetti

Originally one of the front runners for the PM position, but discarded in media due to having direct links to League and thus contradicting statements from 5SM/League. The Lombardi politician is currently the federal secretary of League and a founder of the party, whom has a softer approach to the EU than his party. The politician has also been quoted to be a strong admirer of ECB president Mario Draghi and has strong overseas political ties, particularly in the US.

Andrea Roventini

Another professor considered for the position alongside Conte is Roventini who currently teaches at University of Verona. Chosen by Di Maio as Minister of economy post the announcement of a majority, the professor advocates investments as a driver to economic growth and debt reduction, opposes the Fornero Law (the much-revile pension plans), and has criticised austerity policies in the past.

subject: RANsquawk Daily US Opening News - 21st May 2018
content:
To download the report, please click here
If you would like to subscribe to receive the research sheets directly in your inbox, you can no do so under the Research Suite section of the portal.
To subscribe simply check the box next to "Email these reports" under the desired category.

  • European bourses trading largely positive following an improved risk tone after US/China détente
  • Italian/German 10-Year yield spread at widest point in 7 months ahead of Italian Premier announcement
  • Looking ahead, highlights include, Fed’s Bostic, Harker and Kashkari

 

ASIA-PAC

Asian equity markets traded mostly positive with sentiment underpinned following the conclusion of the 2nd round of US-China trade talks in which China agreed to purchase more goods to avoid a trade war but stopped short of indicating an actual amount it plans to reduce the deficit by. More importantly, US Treasury Secretary Mnuchin announced that tariffs on China would be placed on hold as discussions progress, which eased trade concerns and saw the E-mini S&P gap higher by 0.6% while DJIA futures gained over 200 points. Nikkei 225 (+0.3%) benefitted from a weaker currency, while ASX 200 (-0.1%) lagged behind its regional peers with upside capped by weakness in its largest weighted financials sector as the Royal Banking Commission shifts its attention to Westpac’s business lending practices. Shanghai Comp. (+0.6%) and Hang Seng (+0.6%) outperformed with Chinese bourses the main benefactor of the reduced trade tensions following the postponement of US trade war. Finally, 10yr JGBs were subdued amid gains in stocks and early pressure in T-notes at the open as participants reacted to the trade-related developments, although the latter has since recovered amid reports of block buying from intraday lows.

PBoC skipped open market operations today for a net neutral daily position. (Newswires)

PBoC set CNY mid-point at 6.3852 (Prev. 6.3763)

Japanese Trade Balance Total Yen (Apr) 626.0B vs. Exp. 440.0B (Prev. 797.3B). (Newswires)

Japanese Exports YY (Apr) 7.8% vs. Exp. 8.7% (Prev. 2.1%)

Japanese Imports YY (Apr) 5.9% vs. Exp. 9.8% (Prev. -0.6%)

TRADE

US Treasury Secretary Mnuchin stated that US and China are putting the trade war on hold, while he added that previously announced tariffs on Chinese steel and aluminium, as well as USD 150bln of tariffs on other Chinese imports, would be placed on hold as discussions with China progress. US Treasury Secretary Mnuchin also stated that President Trump is more interested in obtaining a good deal with NAFTA partners rather than quickly concluding talks in time to be voted by Congress this year. (Newswires)

US Trade Representative Lighthizer stated that US may still resort to tariffs and other measures such as restrictions on investment and export regulations unless China makes real structural adjustments to its economy. (Newswires)

EU/UK/US

Italy’s League leader Salvini stated that he agreed with 5-Star Movement Leader Di Maio on choice of Premier and the cabinet for a coalition government, in which neither of the party leaders will become Prime Minister while they will reveal their choice to Italian President Mattarella who will summon them this Monday. Italian President Mattarella has said he sees no obstacles to a Conte Premiership. (ABC News/Newswires)

S&P affirmed Switzerland at 'AAA/A-1+'; Outlook Stable and affirmed Netherlands at 'AAA/A-1+'; Outlook Stable. (Newswires)

UK Rightmove House Prices (May) M/M 0.8% (Prev. 0.4%). (Newswires)

UK Rightmove House Prices (May) Y/Y 1.1% (Prev. 1.6%)

GEOPOLITICS

US President Trump spoke with South Korean President Moon regarding North Korea in which they agreed to work together for a successful summit, while Moon will be visiting the White House on Tuesday to coordinate on the summit. (newswires)

Iran pledged to adhere to the nuclear agreement if EU helps it offset US sanctions. (Newswires)

EQUITIES

European equities trade higher (FTSE 100 +0.8%, CAC 40 +0.7% and IBEX +0.3%) with the absence of German and Swiss stocks in light of Whit Monday. Italy is in focus as the populist leaders agreed on a choice of Premier and cabinet for a coalition government. The party leaders are to meet with Italian President Mattarella this afternoon. Recent reports state that the President does no see any obstacles to a Giuseppe Conte Premiership. Elsewhere the FTSE 100 hit record highs with some credit attributed to FX effects. Sectors are all in the green with outperformance in consumer discretionary and underperformance in financials. In stocks specifics, FTSE 100 heavyweight AstraZeneca (+2.3%) shares are higher amid the FDA approving a treatment.

FX

DXY

The index has now crossed over 94.000 amidst broad Usd gains on the back of a semi-successful conclusion to the latest trade talks between the US and China. In short, concessions have been made on either side and a truce called on tariffs pending further discussions to reach a mutual agreement and ultimately rebalance the lop-sided trade accounts. For the record, 94.064 is the fresh multi-month DXY high and chart-wise 94.200-219 is the next upside target (Fib level), as latest CFTC data reveal a further reduction in short vs all counterparts aside from the Jpy and Cad.

JPY

Stops have finally been tripped at 111.20 vs the Dollar and the obvious nearest bullish objective is 111.50 vs a circa 111.39 peak so far where barrier option offers are reported. 111.00 now becomes support.

NZD/AUD

The Kiwi is back under 0.6900 vs the Usd and 1.0900 vs its antipodean neighbour as significantly weaker than expected NZ retail data compounds the impact of overall Greenback strength and relative Aud resilience just above 0.7500. Hefty option expiry interest this week in Aud/Usd may also be a factor as some 6 bn are housed from 0.7450-0.7550, with 2.3 bn due to run off today by the NY cut at the upper end of that range (0.5 bn at 0.7500 and 1.8 bn at 0.7550).

EUR/GBP

Both softer against the Usd and at deeper lows for 2018, as Eur/Usd slips towards 1.1700 and a major Fib just above the big figure (1.1709) and Cable briefly breaks of 1.3400 to the downside having triggered stops on a break of 1.3450.

CHF

The next worst G10 performer vs the Usd as the headline pair heads back to parity, but Eur/Chf looks set to test 1.1700 without SNB intervention (verbal or actual).

CAD

The Loonie is also holding its own vs the Usd and fending off 1.2900 amidst ongoing strength in crude prices some better Canadian data of late and not that much disappointment after latest NAFTA negotiations failed to strike an accord despite progress on several issues.

EM

No respite for the likes of the Lira, as Usd/Try jumps to just shy of 4.5600 and the Turkish authorities only offer words to address the situation and little tangible to arrest the currency’s slide. Many market observers are now eyeing even more record lows for the Lira unless the CBRT takes decisive/dramatic policy action on June 7.

FIXED INCOME

Bunds took out another interim technical resistance level around 159.01 on their way to a fresh Eurex intraday high at 159.13, but have faded ahead of the next upside objective on some charts that lies at 159.25. However, this is all fundamental and broadly a function of mirroring the fortunes of Italian BTPs that have pared some losses from a 132.92 low (-94 ticks) to reclaim 133.00+ status, which also saw UK debt belatedly join the core safe-haven bid and extended early Liffe gains to 34 ticks at 121.93 before losing momentum. Meanwhile, US Treasuries are largely unresponsive and detached with a greater focus on consolidation after last week’s bear-steepening and contemplating the impact of a US-China trade truce.

COMMODITIES

Oil is currently up with both WTI and Brent +0.3% in-fitting with the broader risk-picture, albeit off best levels alongside fluctuations in the USD. Energy newsflow remains light with the only commentary of note being from IEA's Birol who stated that he sees initial signs of a slowdown in oil demand and they are ready to act.

Elsewhere, gold is at 5 month lows as the USD prints fresh YTD highs with demand for the safe-haven dampened by the risk tone which was also the key factor that propped up copper prices (+0.1%) overnight, especially considering the outperformance in its largest consumer China.

Iron ore is currently down 3%, falling for the fourth straight session on restocking delays in steel mills which has also weighed on steel prices, currently down 1%

content:
EQUITIES

European equities trade mixed (FTSE 100 +0.8%, CAC 40 +0.7%, IBEX +0.3% and FTSE MIB -0.5%) with the absence of German and Swiss stocks in light of Whit Monday. Italy’s FTSE MIB is underperforming yet again amid a slew of ex-dividends fused with political developments over the weekend in which the populist leaders agreed on a choice of Premier and cabinet for a coalition government. The party leaders are to meet with Italian President Mattarella this afternoon. Recent reports state that the President does no see any obstacles to a Giuseppe Conte Premiership. Elsewhere the FTSE 100 hit record highs with some credit attributed to FX effects. Sectors are all in the green with outperformance in industrials and underperformance in financials. In stocks specifics, FTSE 100 heavyweight AstraZeneca (+2.1%) shares are higher amid the FDA approving a treatment.

FX

DXY

The index has now crossed over 94.000 amidst broad Usd gains on the back of a semi-successful conclusion to the latest trade talks between the US and China. In short, concessions have been made on either side and a truce called on tariffs pending further discussions to reach a mutual agreement and ultimately rebalance the lop-sided trade accounts. For the record, 94.064 is the fresh multi-month DXY high and chart-wise 94.200-219 is the next upside target (Fib level), as latest CFTC data reveal a further reduction in short vs all counterparts aside from the Jpy and Cad.

JPY

Stops have finally been tripped at 111.20 vs the Dollar and the obvious nearest bullish objective is 111.50 vs a circa 111.39 peak so far. 111.00 now becomes support.

NZD/AUD

The Kiwi is back under 0.6900 vs the Usd and 1.0900 vs its antipodean neighbour as significantly weaker than expected NZ retail data compounds the impact of overall Greenback strength and relative Aud resilience just above 0.7500. Hefty option expiry interest this week in Aud/Usd may also be a factor as some 6 bn are housed from 0.7450-0.7550, with 2.3 bn due to run off today by the NY cut at the upper end of that range (0.5 bn at 0.7500 and 1.8 bn at 0.7550).

EUR/GBP

Both around 0.35% down vs the Usd and at deeper lows for 2018, as Eur/Usd slips towards 1.1700 and a major Fib just above the big figure (1.1709) and Cable eyes a break of 1.3400 having triggered stops on a break of 1.3450.

CHF

The next worst G10 performer vs the Usd as the headline pair heads back to parity, but Eur/Chf looks set to test 1.1700 without SNB intervention (verbal or actual).

CAD

The Loonie is also holding its own vs the Usd and fending off 1.2900 amidst ongoing strength in crude prices some better Canadian data of late and not that much disappointment after latest NAFTA negotiations failed to strike an accord despite progress on several issues.

EM

No respite for the likes of the Lira, as Usd/Try jumps to just shy of 4.5600 and the Turkish authorities only offer words to address the situation and little tangible to arrest the currency’s slide. Many market observers are now eyeing even more record lows for the Lira unless the CBRT takes decisive/dramatic policy action on June 7.

FIXED INCOME

Bunds took out another interim technical resistance level around 159.01 on their way to a fresh Eurex intraday high at 159.13, but have faded ahead of the next upside objective on some charts that lies at 159.25. However, this is all fundamental and broadly a function of mirroring the fortunes of Italian BTPs that have pared some losses from a 132.92 low (-94 ticks) to reclaim 133.00+ status, which also saw UK debt belatedly join the core safe-haven bid and extended early Liffe gains to 34 ticks at 121.93 before losing momentum. Meanwhile, US Treasuries are largely unresponsive and detached with a greater focus on consolidation after last week’s bear-steepening and contemplating the impact of a US-China trade truce. 

COMMODITIES

Oil is currently up with both WTI and Brent +0.3% in-fitting with the broader risk-picture, albeit off best levels alongside fluctuations in the USD. Energy newsflow remains light with the only commentary of note being from IEA's Birol who stated that he sees initial signs of a slowdown in oil demand and they are ready to act.

Elsewhere, gold is at 5 month lows as the USD prints fresh YTD highs with demand for the safe-haven dampened by the risk tone which was also the key factor that propped up copper prices (+0.1%) overnight, especially considering the outperformance in its largest consumer China.

Iron ore is currently down 3%, falling for the fourth straight session on restocking delays in steel mills which has also weighed on steel prices, currently down 1%.

subject: Short Sterling options: dovish positioning continues
content: Unchanged BoE rates through to Q4 (at least) is the rationale for hefty purchases of 99.500 calls in August and September, with around 100k lots said to have been snapped up for 0.5 tick in a 2 to 1 ratio. This continues mainly upside/dovish activity since May’s MPC meeting and in the run up on multi-data and survey misses. Note, the underlying Sep18 Short Sterling future is currently around 99.230.

UK debt and STIR futures: biding time for busy domestic agenda from Tuesday onward
content: Although Bund stops have been tripped above 158.85, to 159.06 so far (+39 ticks), Gilts are trading more defensively between 121.72-53 vs their previous 121.59 close, in line with a narrowly mixed Short Sterling strip and given several potentially market-moving events on the domestic front unfolding this week from tomorrow. First up, Tuesday’s TSC testimony on the QIR, then CPI, retail sales and the 2nd Q1 GDP release on consecutive days through Friday, while the latest Brexit news is hardly hawkish in terms of BoE policy amidst reports about more revolts against PM May and her EU transition proposals.

subject: ECB says banks borrowed EUR 128mln at marginal rate & deposited EUR 659.144bln; excess liquidity at EUR 1.8735tln
Morning EU Movers: AstraZeneca (AZN LN) +1.6%, BP (BP/ LN) +0.3%, RBS (RBS LN) +0.2%, Ryanair (RYA LN) -1.4%
Bunds: bouncing from early lows, as BTPs suffer further political angst
content: Choppy trade off Monday’s Eurex open for the 10 year German benchmark that was marked down initially to 158.64 and dipped a bit further to 158.61 before regaining a relatively firm bid largely on more Italian debt underperformance awaiting the announcement of a new PM, and in anticipation of fiscal loosening from the populist coalition. Bunds just climbed to 158.82, +15 ticks on the day vs -6 ticks earlier, while the equivalent BTP future has been down to 133.29, -57 ticks, with the yield spread blowing out further and Italian paper also racking up fresh losses against peripheral peers like Spanish Bonos. Technically, the core German bond has effectively respected near term support on the downside and subsequently filled a chart gap, but market contacts do not see additional buying unless the 158.82-85 area is breached (last Friday’s session peak and declining trend-line resistance).

subject: Additional European equity stories post the release of the Daily European equity opening news
content: AstraZeneca (AZN LN) - The FDA has approved a Hyperkalaemia, 1 treatment - Lokelma (formerly ZS-9). (Newswires)

subject: DAILY EUROPEAN EQUITY OPENING NEWS
content:
**EUROPEAN EQUITY COVERAGE WILL ONLY COVER COMPANIES IN THE STOXX 600 OR COMPANIES OF SYSTEMIC IMPORTANCE TO PARTICULAR SECTORS**

**OF NOTE AUSTRIAN, SWISS, GERMAN, NORDIC, ICELANDIC, HUNGARIAN, DANISH AND CANADIAN MARKETS CLOSED TODAY DUE TO NATIONAL HOLIDAYS**

21st May 2018

The Daily European Equity Opening News is uploaded at 0700BST/0100CDT recapping all of the overnight equity news

From 0700BST/0100CDT all equity news will be covered in real time over the audio and headline feed and the full audio rundown will be at 0715BST/0115CDT.

There will be an additional audio rundown at 0750BST/0150CDT recapping any company news which has hit the wires since 0715BST/0115CDT ahead of the European equity open

ASIA

Asian equity markets traded mostly positive with sentiment underpinned following the conclusion of the 2nd round of US-China trade talks in which China agreed to purchase more goods to avoid a trade war but stopped short of indicating an actual amount it plans to reduce the deficit by. More importantly, US Treasury Secretary Mnuchin announced that tariffs on China would be placed on hold as discussions progress, which eased trade concerns and saw the E-mini S&P gap higher by 0.6% while DJIA futures gained over 200 points. Nikkei 225 (+0.4%) benefitted from a weaker currency, while ASX 200 (-0.1%) lagged behind its regional peers with upside capped by weakness in its largest weighted financials sector as the Royal Banking Commission shifts its attention to Westpac’s business lending practices. Shanghai Comp. (+0.8%) and Hang Seng (+1.3%) outperformed with Chinese bourses the main benefactor of the reduced trade tensions following the postponement of US trade war. Finally, 10yr JGBs were subdued amid gains in stocks and early pressure in T-notes at the open as participants reacted to the trade-related developments, although the latter has since recovered amid reports of block buying from intraday lows.

FTSE

Royal Dutch Shell (RDSA LN) – An increasing amount of shareholder groups have backed a resolution at Shell’s AGM on Tuesday that calls for harder carbon targets that are in line with the goals of the Paris climate deal. (Guardian)

AstraZeneca (AZN LN) – The co. is facing protests over the pay of their chief executive as 35% of shareholders voted against the current remuneration plan. (FT)

RBS (RBS LN) – Co. is considering restating dividends on a scale that will rival Lloyds (LLOY LN). The path was cleared for Co. to restart dividends by its USD 4.9bln settlement this month with the US DoJ over the sale of toxic mortgage-backed bonds. (The Times)

GSK (GSK LN) – US and European regulators said they were investigating whether Co.’s drug dolutegravir (a key profit driver for the Co. in recent years) is linked to serious birth defects. (Newswires)

BP (BP/ LN) – Co. CEO says still “not at the point” of increasing dividend, adding that Co. can keep within USD 15bln-17bln CAPEX target range. CEO says Co. has looked at BHP Billiton’s (BLT LN) Shale portfolio and may bid for assets. (Newswires)

BT (BT/A LN) – Co. is considering a sale of its estate of thousands of mobile phone masts for GBP 1.5bln in the fundraising move to help pay for broadband upgrades or reduce the pressure on its cash flow. (Telegraph)

IAG (IAG LN) – The co. is said to offer EUR 1.52bln to buy Norwegian Air. (Newswires)

OTHER UK COMPANIES

Ryanair (RYA LN) – FY profit after tax EUR 1.45bln vs. Exp. EUR 1.44bln.  Co. sees profit after tax for year to end-March 2019 EUR 1.25bln-1.30bln Co. says outlook for FY 2019 on the pessimistic side of cautious, limited H1 and zero H2 visibility. Co. says while still too early to forecast summer bookings, cautiously guiding broadly flat average fares for FY 2019. (Newswires)

DAX

BMW (BMW GY) – The co is expanding the recall fo cars in the UK to 390k (up 88K) after a BBC investigation found some cars cut out completely when driving. (Newswires)

CAC

EDF (EDF FP) – Co. is in talks to sell their 49% stake in a portfolio of UK wind farms which could be valued up to GBP 600mln. (FT)

PAN EUROPE

Enel (ENEL IM) / EDP (EDP PL) – Enel has said they would look at the assets of smaller rival EDP in the case of a break up of EDP. (Newswires)

Banca Monte dei Paschi di Siena (BMPS IM) – The Italian govt has committed to a plan for the lender wherein next year it will define its plan for exiting their stake holding of the bank (Corriere Della Sera)

US

* EQUITIES: SPX -0.26%, NDX -0.51%, DJI +0.01%  SECTORS: Cons Cyclicals: -0.1%, Cons Non-Cyclicals: -0.7%, Energy: -0.8%, Financials: -0.7%, Health Care: +0.4%, Industrials: +0.6%, Materials: +0.2%.

US equity futures sold off at the cash-open and traded mostly rangebound for the rest of the session, with wires keen to attribute the losses to uncertainty around US-China negotiation.

subject: DAILY EUROPEAN OPENING NEWS: Asian equity markets traded mostly positive with sentiment underpinned following the conclusion of the 2nd round of US-China trade talks
content:
Asian equity markets traded mostly positive with sentiment underpinned following the conclusion of the 2nd round of US-China trade talks

China agreed to purchase more goods to avoid a trade war. Mnuchin announced that tariffs on China would be placed on hold as discussions progress

Looking ahead, highlights include ECB’s Nowotny, Fed’s Bostic, Harker and Kashkari

Due to Whit Monday, markets in Austria, Denmark, Germany, Hungary, Iceland, Norway, and Switzerland are closed

TRADE

US Treasury Secretary Mnuchin stated that US and China are putting the trade war on hold, while he added that previously announced tariffs on Chinese steel and aluminium, as well as USD 150bln of tariffs on other Chinese imports, would be placed on hold as discussions with China progress. US Treasury Secretary Mnuchin also stated that President Trump is more interested in obtaining a good deal with NAFTA partners rather than quickly concluding talks in time to be voted by Congress this year. (Newswires)

China agreed to buy more US goods as an effort to avert a trade war, although it refused to commit to US demand to reduce the trade surplus by USD 200bln and did not place a figure for narrowing the trade gap. (Newswires)

US will send a delegation to China for talks regarding agricultural and energy exports, according to a joint statement following the conclusion of the trade talks in Washington. (China Daily)

US Trade Representative Lighthizer stated that US may still resort to tariffs and other measures such as restrictions on investment and export regulations unless China makes real structural adjustments to its economy. (Newswires)

EU and India filed a list of US imports on Friday which may be subject to additional tariffs in retaliation to US steel and aluminium tariffs. (Newswires)

Russian Economy Minister said the US refused to discuss tariffs with Russia within WTO framework and that Russia is considering a response. (Newswires)
 

ASIA

Asian equity markets traded mostly positive with sentiment underpinned following the conclusion of the 2nd round of US-China trade talks in which China agreed to purchase more goods to avoid a trade war but stopped short of indicating an actual amount it plans to reduce the deficit by. More importantly, US Treasury Secretary Mnuchin announced that tariffs on China would be placed on hold as discussions progress, which eased trade concerns and saw the E-mini S&P gap higher by 0.6% while DJIA futures gained over 200 points. Nikkei 225 (+0.4%) benefitted from a weaker currency, while ASX 200 (-0.1%) lagged behind its regional peers with upside capped by weakness in its largest weighted financials sector as the Royal Banking Commission shifts its attention to Westpac’s business lending practices. Shanghai Comp. (+0.8%) and Hang Seng (+1.3%) outperformed with Chinese bourses the main benefactor of the reduced trade tensions following the postponement of US trade war. Finally, 10yr JGBs were subdued amid gains in stocks and early pressure in T-notes at the open as participants reacted to the trade-related developments, although the latter has since recovered amid reports of block buying from intraday lows.

PBoC skipped open market operations today for a net neutral daily position. (Newswires)
PBoC set CNY mid-point at 6.3852 (Prev. 6.3763)

Japanese Trade Balance Total Yen (Apr) 626.0B vs. Exp. 440.0B (Prev. 797.3B). (Newswires)
Japanese Exports YY (Apr) 7.8% vs. Exp. 8.7% (Prev. 2.1%)
Japanese Imports YY (Apr) 5.9% vs. Exp. 9.8% (Prev. -0.6%)


UK/EU

Some UK Conservative MPs are said to preparing for the possibility of a snap election in autumn amid Brexit stalemate. Some MPs have spoken to their local party associations asking to be readopted as prospective parliamentary candidates in readiness for an autumn election. (Times)

UK Foreign Minister Johnson has delivered a thinly-veiled warning to PM May that himself and his fellow Brexiters still expect her to deliver a deal that avoids triggering the “backstop” that would keep Britain aligned to the customs union beyond 2020. (Guardian) The Guardian also reports that a new Commons rebellion to keep Britain in the EU’s customs union for years after Brexit is being prepared by a former Tory minister. Nick Boles, an ex-business minister, said he wanted Britain to remain in the customs union until early 2022, allowing more time to come up with a viable long-term plan. (Guardian)

Arlene Foster of The Democratic Unionist Party leader has reached out to nationalists in Northern Ireland as research revealed that most Catholics find customs checks on the border with the Republic after Brexit “almost impossible to accept”. (Times)

Italy’s League leader Salvini stated that he agreed with 5-Star Movement Leader Di Maio on choice of Premier and the cabinet for a coalition government, in which neither of the party leaders will become Prime Minister while they will reveal their choice to Italian President Mattarella who is expected to summon them this Monday. (ABC News)

S&P affirmed Switzerland at 'AAA/A-1+'; Outlook Stable and affirmed Netherlands at 'AAA/A-1+'; Outlook Stable. (Newswires)

UK Rightmove House Prices (May) M/M 0.8% (Prev. 0.4%). (Newswires)
UK Rightmove House Prices (May) Y/Y 1.1% (Prev. 1.6%)


FX

The greenback began the week firmer and at fresh YTD highs amid the improved tone regarding US trade policy, which effectively helps ease one of the uncertainties for the US economy that the Fed previously highlighted. The USD strength saw EUR/USD print fresh 6-month lows, while pressure in GBP/USD was exacerbated after it broke below its weakest levels for 2018, as Brexit-disarray also weighs with some Conservative MPs said to prepare for the possibility of a snap election in autumn amid Brexit stalemate. Elsewhere, antipodeans were mixed with AUD slightly firmer on cross-related flows and with NZD dampened by disappointing Retail Sales, while USD/JPY reclaimed the 111.00 handle amid the broad positive risk tone and after Exports and Imports added to the recent slew of weaker than expected data for Japan.

New Zealand Retail Sales (Q1) Q/Q 0.1% vs. Exp. 1.0% (Prev. 1.7%). (Newswires)
New Zealand Retail Sales (Q1) Y/Y 3.0% (Prev. 5.4%)

Venezuela election board chief stated there was a 46.1% turnout for Sunday's election which was won by President Maduro. However, Venezuela presidential candidate Falcon said he will not recognize the results of the election because of irregularities, as the government violated the constitution after it placed almost 13,000 pro-government stands near to polling stations. (Newswires)


COMMODITIES

Commodities were mixed overnight with WTI crude futures supported at the open alongside the heightened risk appetite after the implied trade truce between US and China. Elsewhere, gold was pressured with the DXY at fresh YTD highs and with demand for the safe-haven dampened by the risk tone which was also the key factor that propped up copper prices, especially considering the outperformance in its largest consumer China.

US Baker Hughes Total Rig Count (11 May) 1046 (Prev. 1045). (Newswires)

London Metal Exchange is reported to be planning CNY-denominated futures contracts. (Newswires)


GEOPOLITICS

US President Trump spoke with South Korean President Moon regarding North Korea in which they agreed to work together for a successful summit, while Moon will be visiting the White House on Tuesday to coordinate on the summit. (newswires)

Iran pledged to adhere to the nuclear agreement if EU helps it offset US sanctions. (Newswires)
 

US

Treasuries climbed higher on Friday and found buyers after a relatively bearish week for the complex. On the week, the 10yr yields posted its biggest rise in a month. The yield curve saw some modest flattening on Friday, with 2yr yields lower by c.2bps, 10yr and 30yr yields by c.4bps. 2s5s and 2s10s narrowed by c.3bps in the session. US 10yr T-Notes futures settled 10+ ticks higher at 118-27.

Trump legal advisor Giuliani said Special Counsel Mueller will conclude Trump obstruction probe by September 1st. (Russia Today)

The yield curve saw some modest flattening on Friday, with 2yr yields lower by c.2bps, 10yr and 30yr yields by c.4bps. 2s5s and 2s10s narrowed by c.3bps in the session. US 10yr T-Notes futures settled 10+ ticks higher at 118-27.

Trump legal advisor Giuliani said Special Counsel Mueller will conclude Trump obstruction probe by September 1st. (Russia Today)

ASIA-PAC MARKET WRAP: Asia stocks and US equity futures gains on US-China trade truce
content: Asia equity markets traded mostly positive with sentiment underpinned following the conclusion of the 2nd round of US-China trade talks in which China agreed to purchase more goods to avoid a trade war but stopped short of indicating an actual amount it plans to reduce the deficit by. More importantly, US Treasury Secretary Mnuchin announced that tariffs on China would be placed on hold as discussions progress, which eased trade concerns and saw the Emini S&P gap higher by 0.6% while DJIA futures gained over 200 points. Elsewhere, Nikkei 225 (+0.4%) benefitted from a weaker currency, while ASX 200 (-0.1%) lagged behind its regional peers with upside capped by weakness in its largest weighted financials sector as the Royal Banking Commission shifts its attention to Westpac’s business lending practices. Shanghai Comp. (+0.8%) and Hang Seng (+1.3%) outperformed with Chinese bourses the main benefactor of the reduced trade tensions following the postponement of US trade war. Finally, 10yr JGBs were subdued amid gains in stocks and early pressure in T-notes at the open as participants reacted to the trade-related developments, although the latter has since recovered amid reports of block buying from intraday lows.

subject: ASIA-PAC MID-SESSION UPDATE: Asia trades mostly in the green and US equity futures gapped higher after US placed China tariffs on hold
content:
Asia equity markets trade mostly positive with sentiment underpinned following the conclusion of the 2nd round of US-China trade talks in which China agreed to purchase more goods to avoid a trade war, but stopped short of indicating an actual amount it plans to reduce the trade deficit by. More importantly, US Treasury Secretary Mnuchin announced that tariffs on China would be placed on hold as discussions progress, which eased trade concerns and saw the Emini S&P gap higher by 0.6% while the DJIA briefly gained over 200 points. Nikkei 225 (+0.5%) benefits from a weaker currency, while ASX 200 (-0.1%) lags behind its regional peers with upside capped by weakness in its largest weighted financials sector as the Royal Banking Commission shifts its attention to Westpac’s business lending practices. Elsewhere, Shanghai Comp. (+0.7%) and Hang Seng (+1.4%) are the outperformers alongside the reduced trade tensions following the postponement of US tariffs on China.

In FX markets, the greenback begins the week firmer at fresh YTD highs amid the improved tone regarding US trade policy, which effectively helps ease one of the uncertainties for the US economy that the Fed previously highlighted. The USD strength saw EUR/USD print fresh 6-month lows, while GBP/USD eyes its weakest levels for 2018 as Brexit-disarray also weighs with some Conservative MPs reported to prepare for the possibility of a snap election in autumn amid Brexit stalemate. Elsewhere, AUD/USD is firmer on cross-related flows, while USD/JPY reclaimed the 111.00 handle amid the broad positive risk tone and after trade data showed softer than expected exports and imports for Japan.

Finally, 10yr JGBs are subdued amid gains in stocks and early pressure in T-notes at the open as participants reacted to the trade-related developments, although the latter has since recovered amid reports of block buying from intraday lows.
